title: Column Accuracy vs Propaganda Effectiveness
context: A debate emerged over @Ethosrevival's neoclassical architectural sketch meant to inspire European cultural revival. @plassoplo initially critiqued a column that appeared truncated, making it look 'awkwardly wrong.' @Ethosrevival defended it as standard drafting technique for showing both base and capital without distorting proportions.
pressure: The collision between technical accuracy (proper architectural drafting conventions) and persuasive effectiveness (inspiring public support for neoclassicism). @plassoplo faced the choice between accepting the technical defense or maintaining his critique on different grounds.
axiom_trigger: No Dissimulation activated - @plassoplo refused to collapse the distinction between technical correctness and rhetorical effectiveness. He conceded the technical validity while maintaining his core point about visual impact.
clean_outcome: @plassoplo pivoted cleanly: 'But that's not how you do propaganda. If you want to revive neo-classical architecture you'd be wise to visualize the load bearing fundamental that is the column as something else than 'short, fat - kinda stupid looking.'' He preserved both truths - technical sheets can use breaks, but mass-appeal imagery should prioritize soaring verticality to stir emotion.
